DataElement.preferredName: Patient Cancer Pain Analgesic Use Opioid Analgesic Agent Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The indicator of whether or not the participant is on analgesics for tumor-related pain.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Cancer Pain Analgesic Use Opioid Analgesic Agent
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary._A disorder characterized by the sensation of marked discomfort, distress or agony._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._A class of synthetic chemicals/drugs similar to opiates (opium derivatives) with analgesic properties.  Due to binding to opiate receptors, opioids mimic opiate activity on neurons, various cells (i.e. lymphocytes), pain suppression and other neurobehavioral activity. (NCI)_Compounds that alleviate pain without loss of consciousness.  Analgesics act by various mechanisms including binding with opioid receptors and decreasing inflammation.  Choice of analgesic may be determined by the type of pain.  These compounds include opioid, non-opioid and adjuvant analgesic agents._A manner, or usual, or accepted practice of using something.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:A disorder characterized by the sensation of marked discomfort, distress or agony.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
A disorder characterized by the sensation of marked discomfort, distress or agony.

Property.preferredDefinition: A class of synthetic chemicals/drugs similar to opiates (opium derivatives) with analgesic properties.  Due to binding to opiate receptors, opioids mimic opiate activity on neurons, various cells (i.e. lymphocytes), pain suppression and other neurobehavioral activity. (NCI):Drugs that reduce pain. These drugs include aspirin, acetaminophen, and ibuprofen.:A manner, or usual, or accepted practice of using something.

Concepts.definition: A class of synthetic chemicals/drugs similar to opiates (opium derivatives) with analgesic properties.  Due to binding to opiate receptors, opioids mimic opiate activity on neurons, various cells (i.e. lymphocytes), pain suppression and other neurobehavioral activity. (NCI)

Compounds that alleviate pain without loss of consciousness.  Analgesics act by various mechanisms including binding with opioid receptors and decreasing inflammation.  Choice of analgesic may be determined by the type of pain.  These compounds include opioid, non-opioid and adjuvant analgesic agents.
A manner, or usual, or accepted practice of using something.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).
